io.seanbailey.sql

Class Model

  • java.lang.Object
    • io.seanbailey.sql.Model
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    User

    public abstract class Model
extends java.lang.Object
    Models can be automatically translated to and from SQL. You can also use the methods defined in this class to effectively query the database using an SQLChain.
    Since:
    2018-05-10
    Version:
    1.0
    Author:
    Sean Bailey
    See Also:
    SQLChain

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      Model() 

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Static Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      static SQLChain all(java.lang.Class<? extends Model> clazz)
      Starts an SQLChain, that can return every instance of a model.
      static SQLChain find(java.lang.Class<? extends Model> clazz, java.lang.String attribute, java.lang.Object object)
      Starts an SQLChain, that lets you find a single instance of a model.
      static SQLChain where(java.lang.Class<? extends Model> clazz, java.lang.String condition, java.lang.Object object)
      Starts an SQLChain, that can be used to query the database for a particular set of models.

        public Model()

    • Method Detail

      • all

        public static SQLChain all(java.lang.Class<? extends Model> clazz)
        Starts an SQLChain, that can return every instance of a model.
        Parameters:
        clazz - Class to retrieve
        Returns:
        an SQLChain for further additions.

      • where

        public static SQLChain where(java.lang.Class<? extends Model> clazz,
                             java.lang.String condition,
                             java.lang.Object object)
        Starts an SQLChain, that can be used to query the database for a particular set of models. Internally this makes use of prepared statements, so you don't need to worry about SQL injections.
        Parameters:
        clazz - Class to retrieve.
        condition - a condition that all retrieved models will meet. It should be written in the form "attribute = ?" or "attribute > ?". A question mark is used to mark the point that the object should be inserted. You may also use the shorthand form "attribute", in which case "attribute = ?" will be inferred.
        object - Any Java object that can be inserted into a prepared statement. It takes the place of the question mark in the condition.
        Returns:
        an SQLChain for further additions.

      • find

        public static SQLChain find(java.lang.Class<? extends Model> clazz,
                            java.lang.String attribute,
                            java.lang.Object object)
        Starts an SQLChain, that lets you find a single instance of a model.
        Parameters:
        clazz - Class to retrieve.
        attribute - Attribute to check object against. Must be unique.
        object - Object to compare to attribute.
        Returns:
        an SQLChain for further additions.
